text: hi everyone
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
boy Genius album The Record finally we
have the debut full-length LP of the
Indie singer songwriters super Trio
consisting of Phoebe Bridgers Julian
Baker and Lucy dacus uh that would be
boy Genius who amidst growing careers
decided to form like Voltron in 2018 and
release a very critically acclaimed EP
and since the release of this record all
their profiles have respectively grown
becoming some of the most significant
voices on the Underground songwriter
circuit with Phoebe even making some
mainstream moves with some recent media
appearances she was also on the new
Sizzle record for a moment in all the
Mayhem of new fans opportunities and
albums it seemed like the boy Genius
Trio had been kind of shelved which
honestly would be understandable but the
girls actually came through with a
record ingeniously titled the record
which almost has a this is what you
wanted wasn't it toned to it but
listening to it this album doesn't sound
like it's coming from a place of
bitterness or annoyance quite the
opposite sounds like the girls put a lot
of heart into this one and effectively
explore their respective Styles while
making their collaborative efforts work
in harmony now I get maybe that doesn't
seem like a huge feat because creatively
there is more overlap than there is
dissonance between Phoebe Julian and
Lucy I mean that's kind of why they're
collaborating in the first place but
what they've offered on this record does
sound a lot more cohesive and ambitious
than much of the material on the 2018 ep
the intro cut without you without them
literally sees the three of them singing
in a lovely series of three-part
harmonies the tune and lyrics strangely
sound like something from a bygone era
the song is gorgeous it's sentimental
reminding me of points of the opening
moments from the debut Fleet Foxes
record but from this track we quickly
make a jarring transition back to 2023
with the cut twenty dollars which is a
very meat and potatoes indie rock song
led by Julian Baker in my opinion this
track is a pretty significant dip off
the bat mostly because the drums and
electric guitars sound so overblown and
basic in terms of their performance and
writing the track doesn't really bring
the Nuance that fans respectively expect
from each of these artists solo works
though I suppose the enraged finish is
pretty cool the track anti-curse later
on the lp has a similar mix of middling
lows and blaring highs as well and
there's actually a handful of more
Rockin cuts on the project and
thankfully the other ones are slightly
better there's the shimmering indie folk
Rock ballad not strong enough which has
some of the strongest lyrics on the
entire LP which read like a depressive
spiral or a fever dream the building
always an angel never a god refrain
toward the end of the track is a
highlight too but I don't know the
production the instrumentation on this
track just feels so nice boy Genius just
very non-specific it's like they
couldn't agree on something unique so
they settled on an instrumental that
feels like the soundtrack to a heart
medication commercial and I feel the
same with the song True Blue to a degree
as well then there's Satanist which I
think is my favorite heavy hitter of the
bunch here the track is led by The Sassy
post grunge riffs something that sounds
lifted out of an Avril vein or like a
lit song I'm really just waiting for a
pop punk tick tocker to rush in and hit
me with some nursery rhymes loaded with
swears as soon as I hear the opening on
this thing but boy Genius drum up their
own brand of reverence here that works
trading off verses between each other in
the process inviting listeners to be
satanists and nihilists and sell their
souls sleep in cars and kill the
bourgeoisie in a very cheeky way hearing
this I'm envisioning a music video where
the trio is like driving a car off a
bridge or lighting a couch on fire with
a flamethrower and frankly it rules plus
like I mentioned earlier I love that
every everybody on the track gets a
moment to kind of say their peace and
shine that same collaborative magic is
part of what makes the track cool about
it so strong too now the most
devastating moments on this project in
my opinion are often the subtlest there
is Emily I'm sorry which is an acoustic
cut backed with some gently pulsating
beats and top by Bridgers trademark
hushed vocal delivery she tells the
story of a love with a lot of very
complicated and tense and standoffish
feelings that are so potent in the
lyrics I kind of get secondhand anxiety
off of hearing about them the
instrumentation the performance is so
weary it's so moody it's hard not to get
wrapped up in it especially with such
beautiful Harmony accompaniment coming
from Lucy and Julian Phoebe fans will
also most likely be rocked by the
twinkly arpeggios lullaby Vibes and
deeply depressive feelings of Revolution
zero not surprised to see some of the
lyrics on this track going on about
Phoebe's love of Elliott Smith the
inspiration she's taken from him and his
music like there's also a lush and
ornate finish at the end of this track
that makes for one of the prettiest
moments on the album then there's where
in love which is a big dacus moment on
the record that cuts deep right from the
start with lines like you could
absolutely break my heart that's how I
know that we're in love then we move to
a cinematic midpoint where she describes
going to karaoke there's some swelling
strings in the mix too as Lucy goes on
I'm just hanging on every word which is
a testament to her Talent as a
songwriter not only that but we have
what is easily the most lyrically dense
and focused cut on the entire record
just being reigned by her the closing
cut on this thing is a strong finisher
and really one for the fans given that
in a way it is a melodic and a narrative
callback to the song Me and my dog from
the 2018 ep the pianos the strings the
vocals are all lovely but it's really
the lyrical Revelations on this track
that I think hit the hardest which at
least personally I read very much much
being about
being ready to be happy and just let go
of the toxic desires and tragic events
of the past which for a record like this
I think is a great note to end on I'll
say what I wanted out of this record for
the most part I got some moments in the
track list felt like less of a communal
moment than others and some of the
production kind of sounds like the trios
merely just singing over something that
comes across like an agreeable lowest
common denominator as opposed to an
instrumental path that would actually
stand out in the wider field of indie
rock and indie folk that being said it
is pretty hard generally I would say to
work as a cohesive unit with three
distinct songwriting voices but on the
record the trio proves that's more than
possible I'm feeling a strong seven on
this thing transition have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should I review next hit the like if you
like Please Subscribe and please don't
cry hit the Bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel Anthony fantano
boy Genius of forever
